title: Remove version upper bound on `pyyaml`
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->
This PR removes the upper bound on `pyyaml`, thus allowing installation of PyYAML 6 and resolving the issues outlined in #2285. This is a blocking issue in order to use the GCP DeepLearning VM images (e.g. `projects/deeplearning-platform-release/global/images/pytorch-1-13-cpu-v20230807-debian-11-py310`), which come with PyYAML 6 already installed.

title: [K8s] Zero config networking for Kubernetes
body:
This PR introduces new networking features for our Kubernetes support. In particular, we no longer need opening many ports on the Kubernetes cluster nodes. Now we support two modes of operation:

1. `portforward`: Open no ports, and we use `kubectl port-forward` under the hood to reach the pods. This requires zero configuration on the user's end, and is only marginally worse (~10%) in performance (see benchmarks). Given the significantly better UX, this will the default mode of operation. 
2. `nodeport`: Open 1 port, and we run a ssh jump pod on that port to reach other pods. This requires opening one port on any one node in the Kubernetes cluster, and offers the highest performance while minimizing the number of open ports needed.

Users who don't want to use `portforward` can switch to `nodeport` by modifying their `~/.sky/config` file:
```
kubernetes:
  networking: nodeport
```

Note that we currently create one jump pod per user. Eventually, we want to share the jump pod across many users (See #2499)

--------
This PR also has other bug fixes, including populating k8s envvars when the user runs SSH (#2287 and #2453 will also be closed by this PR).

Thanks to @landscapepainter, @aviweit and @hemildesai for their contributions.

Tested (run the relevant ones):

- [x] Code formatting: `bash format.sh`
- [x] `pytest tests/test_smoke.py --kubernetes -k "not TestStorageWithCredentials"`
- [x] Ensure #2453 is fixed

title: [Core] Support Multiple Resources
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

This partially builds upon an old PR #1389. 
The user can specify an ordered _preference list_ or an unordered _restriction set_ for accelerators.
_Ordered preference list_. The user prefers `A100-40GB:1` over `V100:1`, etc. The optimizer will follow user-specified order in picking the accelerators.
```
accelerators: ['A100-40GB:1', 'V100:1', 'K80:1', 'T4:1']
```
_Unordered restriction set_. The user specifies multiple accelerators for accelerator to choose from, with no preference among them.
```
accelerators: {'A100-40GB:1', 'K80:1', 'V100:1', 'T4:1', 'T4:4'}
```

title: [k8s] Possible fix for: Could not resolve hostname: Temporary failure in name resolution.
body:
When multiple ray clusters exist in a same kubernetes cluster and one of them is being removed by `sky down` then a wrong entry might be deleted from `~/.ssh/config` that could then lead to an ssh error when attempting to ssh into ray head of a remaining cluster.

Current kubernetes support (in master branch) uses NodePort to access ray clusters where the IP is the same for all ray nodes.

The PR updates `found` criteria at `remove_cluster` to search for `Host <cluster name>`.

title: [UX] Make logger safe with rich status
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Previously, the `logger.info/warning/etc` will conflict with the rich status, causing the logging message appearing in the same line as the spinner. This PR fixes it by stopping and restarting the spinner when the message is being printed.


This PR is introduced for #2481, but should be generally useful for other places where `logger` and `rich.Status` is being used together.

title: [Provisioner] Update ports for UP cluster
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

This PR introduces the ability to update ports. When you execute `sky launch -c existing-cluster port.yaml`, it will automatically detect ports that have not been opened and open them. All opened ports will be closed when the cluster is tear down.

`sky exec` will continue to check port requirements and will not execute any task if the required ports haven't been opened in the cluster.

Also, this PR:
* Accept single ports argument;
* Add CLI option for ports;
* Change the internal type of ports to `List[str]`.

<!-- Describe the tests ran -->
<!-- Unit tests (tests/test_*.py) are part of GitHub CI; below are tests that launch on the cloud. -->

Tested (run the relevant ones):

- [x] Code formatting: `bash format.sh`
- [x] Any manual or new tests for this PR (please specify below)

AWS:
```bash
sky launch --cloud aws -c aw
# Login to AWS console to check it is using default shared SG
sky launch --cloud aws -c aw --ports 10022
# Login to AWS console to check it is using dedicated shared SG, with an inbound rule of 10022
sky launch --cloud aws -c aw --ports 10000-10040
# Login to AWS console to check it is using dedicated shared SG, with an inbound rule of 10000-10021 and 10023-10040
# Run some HTTP server on the ports and curl in the local machine
sky down aw
# Check the sg is correctly cleaned up

# Backward compatibility: launch a cluster in the current master
sky launch ports.yaml --cloud aws -c aw-back # Some yaml with ports specified
# The cluster should already using dedicated sg
# Change to this branch
sky launch -c aw-back --ports <a-different-port>
# Check the dedicatedsg inbound rule, it should have one more rule with the new ports
sky down aw-back
# Check the sg is correctly cleaned up

# Test for 2 node
sky launch --cloud aws --num-nodes 2 -c aw-2node
# It should using default sg
sky launch -c aw-2node --ports 10022
# All of the instance should changed to the new dedicated sg
```
GCP:
```bash
sky launch --cloud gcp -c gc
# Login to the GCP VPC Network page to check there is no firewall rule
sky launch --cloud gcp -c gc --ports 10022
# Login to the GCP VPC Network page to check there is a firewall rule named `sky-ports-gc{some hash here}`, with 10022
sky launch --cloud gcp -c gc --ports 20000-30000 --ports 10000-10040
# Login to the GCP VPC Network page to check the previous rule, it should have two protocol/ports with 10000-10040 and 20000-30000
# Run some HTTP server on the ports and curl in the local machine
sky down gc
# Check the firewall rule is correctly cleaned up

# Backward compatibility: launch a cluster in the current master
sky launch ports.yaml --cloud gcp -c gc-back # Some yaml with ports specified
# There should have some firewall rule named `user-ports-{cluster_name}-{ports}`
# Change to this branch
sky launch -c gc-back --ports <a-different-port>
# There should be another rule named `sky-ports-{cluster_name}`
sky down gc-back
# Two of them should be cleaned up
```
Azure:
```bash
sky launch --cloud azure -c az
# Login to the Azure console, find the resource group, and check there is no redundant rule in the nsg
sky launch --cloud azure -c az --ports 10022
# Check the nsg. It should have one 10022 rule now
# Run some HTTP server on the ports and curl in the local machine
```

title: [k8s] Zero config networking for Kubernetes
body:
This PR introduces new networking features for our Kubernetes support. In particular, we no longer need opening many ports on the Kubernetes cluster nodes. Now we support two modes of operation:

1. `portforward`: Open no ports, and we use `kubectl port-forward` under the hood to reach the pods. This requires zero configuration on the user's end, but might be slightly worse in performance for moving large amounts of data (needs to benchmarked). This will the default mode of operation. (Contributed by @landscapepainter)
2. `nodeport`: Open 1 port, and we run a ssh jump pod on that port to reach other pods. This requires opening one port on any one node in the Kubernetes cluster, and offers the highest performance. (Contributed by @aviweit)

Users who don't want to use `portforward` can switch to `nodeport` by modifying their `~/.sky/config` file:
```
kubernetes:
  networking: nodeport
```

This PR also has other bug fixes, including populating k8s envvars when the user runs SSH (#2287) (Contributed by @hemildesai). 

This PR will be rebased and opened after GPU support (#2328) is merged to master.

PRs to merge:

title: [k8s_cloud_beta1] Sky down for a cluster deployed in Kubernetes to possibly remove sshjump pod.
body:
Minimize the chances for having a dangling sshjump pod by adding a logic to `terminate_node` of Kubernetes provider - to remove sshjump pod and its service, in case sshjump pod is being reported as having its container not ready.

Otherwise, the sshjump pod is being reported with its main container ready where its lcm takes care of the cleaning i.e. terminates that pod and service.

title: [k8s_cloud_beta1] Adding support for ssh using kubectl port-forward to access k8s instance
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->
This PR allows to set up an ssh session to access k8s instance through a jump pod using `kubectl port-forward` and `socat` as a `Proxycommand`. Default ssh method would be to use `kubectl port-forward` and `socat`, and if the user wants to open up a `NodePort` service to access the jump pod instead, the following can be written in `~/.sky/config.yaml`:

```
kubernetes:
  networking: nodeport
```

Note: Allowing to use `ControlMaster` that is set from `ssh_options_list()` causes `ControlPersist `amount of seconds of stalling whenever `ssh` command is ran while running `sky` commands in some linux distributions(ubuntu 22.04, debian 11 seems to be okay, but debian 10 has the stalling issue). This is resolved in this PR by disallowing the use of `ControlMaster` for k8s instances.

<!-- Describe the tests ran -->

title: [Core] Fix the optimization for IP fetching in `sky launch`
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

The previous optimization for IP fetching does not work as we did not retrieve the internal IP from the provision output, causing the `sky launch` will always fetch the IP addresses causing additional overheads.

This PR fixes the optimization. The following is the profiling, which shows `~9s` faster for launching a new cluster and `~13s` faster for `sky launch` an existing cluster. Note the optimization is for single node only at the moment, but since many users are using single node, it should be helpful.

Profiling (average over 5 runs, on GCP with 2 CPUs, `time sky launch -y -d`):
- Original:
  `sky launch` a new cluster: 2m 41s
  `sky launch` an existing cluster: 1m 26s
- Current PR:
  `sky launch` a new cluster: 2m 32s
  `sky launch` an existing cluster: 1m 13s

TODO:

title: [Core] Filter out cloud that does not support multi node early
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Our unsupported feature check in the optimizer does not include the multi-node feature. That will make the optimizer output including some clouds that do not support that feature. This will help #2352 fail early, when the `specific_reservations` is specified and multiple nodes are used -- excluding it from the optimizer table, instead of failing during the provisioning.

To reproduce (SCP below does not support multiple nodes):
```
sky launch --num-nodes 2  ✱
```

title: [k8s_cloud_beta1] Add minio object store support.
body:
We have an on-prem installation of minio object store, which is S3 compatible. We had been able to add minio support to SkyPilot and test it against our local installation with Kubernetes (`kubeadm` based and `kind`).

We added example tasks under `examples/storage/minio` and updated `tests/test_smoke.py` that can be invoked via:

```
pytest -v tests/test_smoke.py  --generic-cloud kubernetes -m minio --minio
```

Please find below a setup example:

1. Start minio container: 

```
docker run -p 9000:9000 -d -p 9001:9001 -e "MINIO_ROOT_USER=minio99" -e "MINIO_ROOT_PASSWORD=minio123" quay.io/minio/minio server /data --console-address ":9001"
```

2. Loginto minio web ui (localhost port 9001) with above minio root user/password. Select Access Key at left pane and generate it.

3. Create ~/.sky/config.yaml with minio endpoint:
```
    minio:
        endpoint: "http://<your minio host name>:9000"
```

4. Invoke AWS CLI to set access and secretes keys (generated in the step above). For rest prompts - enter defaults.
```
AWS_SHARED_CREDENTIALS_FILE=~/.minio/minio.credentials aws configure --profile minio
```

5. Invoke `sky check`. Kubernetes and minio should pass.

title: [FIX] Fix no new line bug when installing sky auto completion
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Currently, when installing, skypilot will write `# For SkyPilot shell completion\n. ~/.sky/.sky-complete.zsh` to the end of `~/.zshrc`. If there are no new line at the end of `~/.zshrc`, the comment will append at the last line, such as:

```bash
alias gs="git status"# For SkyPilot shell completion
. ~/.sky/.sky-complete.zsh
```

which will cause some bugs such as:

```bash
git: 'status#' is not a git command. See 'git --help'.

The most similar command is
        status
```

This PR add a `\n` before the comment to avoid such bug.

title: [FIX] SkyCallback not working on newer version of Python
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Fix #2363 

According to [docs](https://docs.python.org/3.7/library/collections.html#:~:text=Deprecated%20since%20version%203.3%2C%20will%20be%20removed%20in%20version%203.9%3A%20Moved%20Collections%20Abstract%20Base%20Classes%20to%20the%20collections.abc%20module.%20For%20backwards%20compatibility%2C%20they%20continue%20to%20be%20visible%20in%20this%20module%20through%20Python%203.8.), It looks like Collections Abstract Base Classes are moved to the second-level module since Python 3.3, but had been available for backwards compatibility through Python 3.8. So existing code can be ran on Python 3.8, but no on Python >= 3.9.
Since SkyPilot's Python dependency is Python >= 3.7 according to [your docs](https://skypilot.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting-started/installation.html#enabling-shell-completion:~:text=SkyPilot%20requires%20python%20%3E%3D%203.7), it should works as intended.
Fortunately, this change was made in Python 3.3, the second-level module is available for Python >= 3.3. So the fix is very simple, and works fine.

<!-- Describe the tests ran -->
